etymologies: early 20th century (in sense ‘each of four hypothetical elements regarded as forming the basis of all the other elements’): from Greek, neuter of prōtos ‘first’. The modern sense is first recorded in 1920

definitions: a stable subatomic particle occurring in all atomic nuclei, with a positive electric charge equal in magnitude to that of an electron, but of opposite sign.

notes.text: The mass of the proton is 1,836 times greater than that of the electron. The atoms of each chemical element have a characteristic number of protons in the nucleus; this is known as the atomic number. The common isotope of hydrogen has a nucleus consisting of a single proton

shortDefinitions: stable subatomic particle occurring in all atomic nuclei
